posts.post_content:
Szadek begs for a [Howl from Beyond](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Howl from Beyond). Just 6 mana (if you've hardcasted Szadek you're doing it wrong) and the third hit from him will make the milled total 55 cards, rather than the fourth hit :D  
Also, if you're getting stuff into play from free, why not splash red and use [Brion Stoutarm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Brion Stoutarm), and in a multiplayer you can kill two opponents in one round. Mill one to death (55 is usually lethal) and then sacrifice Szadek with Brion to deal massive damage.  
Don't forget a few [Cerulean Wisps](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cerulean Wisps) and szadek is a massive blocker as well :)
posts.html:

Posted By: avimkv (10/19/2012 11:10:09 AM)

posts.post_content:
The secretive House Dimir prizes subtlety and subterfuge above all else. Szadek, despite being their guild master, is nonetheless a very *un*subtle card. While it could be argued that this is a failing on the designers' parts, I think it actually makes sense: A Dimir-themed deck will have likely been spending the bulk of the game Transmuting cards into answers, stalling, and gaining control. Szadek, like all guild leaders, is designed to be that deck's masterstroke: Not only does he tie into the guild's milling subtheme, he is a card that demands an *immediate* answer, and if House Dimir has been playing its cards wisely, by the time Szadek comes down, it will be far, far too late for the opponent to be able to break through your defenses and counterspells before Szadek cleans things up.  
  
Flavorwise, one must recall that Szadek is not just popping out of nowhere: Rather, his appearance is the culmination of *ten thousand years* of subversion, espionage, and manipulation... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
The secretive House Dimir prizes subtlety and subterfuge above all else. Szadek, despite being their guild master, is nonetheless a very unsubtle card. While it could be argued that this is a failing on the designers' parts, I think it actually makes sense: A Dimir-themed deck will have likely been spending the bulk of the game Transmuting cards into answers, stalling, and gaining control. Szadek, like all guild leaders, is designed to be that deck's masterstroke: Not only does he tie into the guild's milling subtheme, he is a card that demands an immediate answer, and if House Dimir has been playing its cards wisely, by the time Szadek comes down, it will be far, far too late for the opponent to be able to break through your defenses and counterspells before Szadek cleans things up.

Flavorwise, one must recall that Szadek is not just popping out of nowhere: Rather, his appearance is the culmination of ten thousand years of subversion, espionage, and manipulation... (see all)

posts.post_content:
I don't understand why so many people like this card so much. It mills your opponent like crazy, but it'll still usually takes at least three turns to deck somebody; 5+10+20= 35. And oftentimes it'll take four.   
  
[Inkwell Leviathan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Inkwell Leviathan), [Stormtide Leviathan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stormtide Leviathan), [Pestilence Demon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name= Pestilence Demon) and even [Commander Greven il-Vec](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Commander Greven il-Vec) are all more consistent and useful on-color big-creature finishers, even in a mill deck... Because if you need a big creature finisher in a mill deck, chances are that your mill isn't working anyways.   
  
Even in it's block, [Sanguine Praetor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sanguine Praetor) gave it competition as "best finisher" card in its colors. This guy just doesn't make sense in so many of the casual and extended decks I've seen him in.
posts.html:
I don't understand why so many people like this card so much. It mills your opponent like crazy, but it'll still usually takes at least three turns to deck somebody; 5+10+20= 35. And oftentimes it'll take four.

Inkwell Leviathan, Stormtide Leviathan, Pestilence Demon and even Commander Greven il-Vec are all more consistent and useful on-color big-creature finishers, even in a mill deck... Because if you need a big creature finisher in a mill deck, chances are that your mill isn't working anyways.

Even in it's block, Sanguine Praetor gave it competition as "best finisher" card in its colors. This guy just doesn't make sense in so many of the casual and extended decks I've seen him in.
